definition:
A *hemimetric* on a set $X$ is a function
$d\colon X\times X\to {\mathbb{R}}$ such that

1.  $d(x,y)\geq 0$;

2.  $d(x,z) \leq d(x,y) + d(y,z)$;

3.  $d(x,x) = 0$;

for all $x,y,z\in X$.

Hence, essentially $d$ is a metric which fails to satisfy symmetry and
the property that distinct points have positive distance. A hemimetric
induces a topology on $X$ in the same way that a metric does, a basis of
open sets being $$\{B(x,r): x\in X, r>0\},$$ where
$B(x,r)=\{y\in X : d(x,y)<r\}$ is the $r$-ball centered at $x$.
